meta.name: Description

head.title: Enhanced Thermal Dehydrogenation of Ammonia Borane by d-Mannitol | Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research

meta.content: Enhanced Thermal Dehydrogenation of Ammonia Borane by d-Mannitol

Hydrogen release from solid-state ammonia borane (AB, NH3BH3) exhibits a long induction period and requires a relatively high temperature. In the present work, d-mannitol (DM, C6H8(OH)6) was used as an additive to enhance the hydrogen release properties of AB. At proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell operating temperatures, the influence of various operating process parameters (temperature and heating rate) and AB–DM ratio has been investigated. In addition, the composition of gaseous products was analyzed to identify the reaction mechanism using mass spectrometry. In particular, the formation of ammonia, which poisons PEM fuel cells, was quantitatively analyzed. Using solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance, solid products were characterized to better understand the mechanism of AB thermolysis. In the presence of DM, the onset reaction temperature decreased to 80 °C, whereas dehydrogenation kinetics were significantly improved. With DM as an additive, we obtained a high hydrogen yield of 9.1 wt % (1.75 H2 equivalent) at the PEM fuel cell operating temperature (90 °C).

div.p:
Hydrogen release from solid-state ammonia borane (AB, NH
3
BH
3
) exhibits a long induction period and requires a relatively high temperature. In the present work,
d
-mannitol (DM, C
6
H
8
(OH)
6
) was used as an additive to enhance the hydrogen release properties of AB. At proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell operating temperatures, the influence of various operating process parameters (temperature and heating rate) and AB–DM ratio has been investigated. In addition, the composition of gaseous products was analyzed to identify the reaction mechanism using mass spectrometry. In particular, the formation of ammonia, which poisons PEM fuel cells, was quantitatively analyzed. Using solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance, solid products were characterized to better understand the mechanism of AB thermolysis. In the presence of DM, the onset reaction temperature decreased to 80 °C, whereas dehydrogenation kinetics were significantly improved. With DM as an additive, we obtained a high hydrogen yield of 9.1 wt % (1.75 H
2
equivalent) at the PEM fuel cell operating temperature (90 °C).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Along with the high efficiency of proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells, hydrogen has received great attention as an energy alternative to fossil fuels because it has the highest calorific value per mass (150 kJ/kg). Hydrogen released from the anode reacts with oxygen at the cathode to produce heat, electricity, and water as by-products in PEM fuel cells, which operate at relatively low temperatures (<100 °C).
(1)
Despite these favorable properties, the development of hydrogen-powered PEM fuel cell applications is being delayed by some drawbacks, such as low gravimetric and volumetric densities and lack of safety. Thus, it is highly desirable to develop efficient methods to generate hydrogen at PEM fuel cell operating temperatures, which enables the utilization of waste heat without sacrificing extra energy.

Among the hydrogen storage materials, ammonia borane (NH
3
BH
3
: AB) has attracted extensive interest as a promising candidate because of its high hydrogen content (19.6 wt %), decomposition under moderate conditions, and stability at room temperature.
(2−5)
Hydrogen can be released from AB through either hydrolysis or thermolysis. It has also been proposed to combine these two approaches in hydrothermolysis, where the AB–water mixture is heated.
(6−8)

By hydrolysis, AB can release hydrogen at a relatively low temperature (i.e., room temperature) in the presence of a catalyst. Unfortunately, this provides a low theoretical hydrogen yield and a significant production of ammonia which poisons the anode catalyst in PEM fuel cells.
(2)
AB hydrolysis also generates a considerable amount of B–O bonds, which are not desirable from the regeneration viewpoint. As compared to hydrolysis, AB thermolysis has the capability of high hydrogen yield in addition to decreased production of ammonia and no B–O bond formation.
(7,9−11)
It is well known that the products of thermolysis are preferred for regeneration as they are thermodynamically more unstable than those formed by hydrolysis.
(12−14)
However, thermolysis requires a high temperature (>150 °C) to obtain a reasonable amount of hydrogen from AB (>2 equiv of hydrogen per AB). Furthermore, H
2
release from neat solid-state AB exhibits slow kinetics, a long induction period, and low hydrogen yield.
(11,15,16)
AB thermolysis also produces ammonia that must be removed but of significantly lower amounts than that during hydrolysis.
(17,18)

Considerable effort has been made to find alternative catalysts and additives to overcome the shortcomings of AB thermolysis mentioned above. Gutowska et al.
(19)
reported that the half-reaction time was significantly reduced by adding mesoporous silica, even at 50 °C, as compared to neat AB (half-reaction time of 290 min at 80 °C). Nakagawa et al.
(20)
systematically investigated the effects of metal additives with AB. They found that metal chlorides were effective to decrease the onset temperature and the amount of by-product gas. Hydrogen was observed to be released at 59 °C when CoCl
2
or NaCl
2
was used as an additive.

In our prior work, it was found that with an effective management of exothermic heat during the first H
2
release (
eq 1
) from AB, this can be utilized to initiate the release of the second H
2
(
eq 2
).
(10,15)
Using 20 wt % of quartz wool or boric acid as additives, high material-based hydrogen yields (2.2–2.3 H
2
equivalent) were obtained at near PEM fuel cell operating temperatures (85–90 °C). Pan et al.
(21)
studied the effect of mannitol as an additive on AB dehydrogenation and found that the hydroxyl group in mannitol plays a role in enhancing the H
2
-release properties of AB. Along with the improved evolution of H
2
, however, increased formation of ammonia and undesirable B–O bonds was also observed because the key reaction intermediate is the hydroxyl group, which generally participates in the hydrolysis of AB (
eq 3
). Their study did not make quantitative analysis of the hydrogen and ammonia produced. In this context, from a PEM fuel cell application viewpoint, it is important to find the optimal conditions in which hydrogen yield is maximized, whereas the hydrolysis products such as ammonia and B–O bonds are minimized.
(1)
(2)
(3)

In this study, the effect of
d
-mannitol (DM) as an additive was further investigated to improve the H
2
release performance while reducing undesirable products at PEM fuel cell operating temperatures by varying the operating parameters, such as AB–DM ratio, temperature, pressure, and heating rate. Also, the extent of participation of the hydroxyl group was quantified indirectly by measuring ammonia formation. Furthermore, transient mass spectrometry analysis of the gaseous product was performed to understand the reaction mechanism. Finally, solid products were characterized by solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
As illustrated in
Figure
1
, experiments were performed using a stainless steel batch reactor (Parr Instruments Inc., model 4592). The samples (0.5 g) were prepared by mixing AB (purity 97% NH
3
BH
3
, Sigma-Aldrich Co.) uniformly with DM (purity 97%; C
6
H
8
(OH)
6
, VWR Co.) using a vortex mixer and placed in a quartz vial (5 mL) inside the reactor. Before the experiment, the reactor was purged with nitrogen. Starting at room temperature, the reactor was heated at a constant heating rate (β) to the set-point temperature (
T
SP
). Along with the reactor pressure, both the sample (
T
S
) and reactor (
T
R
) temperatures were monitored with time. Finally, the gaseous products of AB thermolysis were captured in a sampling bag to measure the NH
3
concentration using a Dräger tube. The experimental details are discussed elsewhere.
(7)
The hydrogen yield and equivalent are calculated as
(4)
(5)

div.p: Figure 1. Schematic of the stainless steel batch reactor system.

div.div:
H
2
molar equivalent is defined as the number of H
2
moles released per mole of AB, whereas the overall or material-based H
2
yield is the weight ratio of H
2
generated to a mixture of AB and an additive, which are involved in AB dehydrogenation.

Temperature-programmed desorption with mass spectrometry (TPD/MS) analysis was carried out using an AutoChem 2920 (Micromeritics Co.). For TPD analysis, 0.1 g of the sample was pretreated by purging argon gas at room temperature for 30 min. With increasing temperature at 10 °C/min up to 90 °C, the gas released from the TPD system was analyzed using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS 422).

The
11
B solid-state NMR spectra were obtained using a Varian Unity Inova 300 MHz spectrometer (7.05 T), operating at a resonance frequency of ν
0
(
11
B) = 96.3 MHz at room temperature. A Varian/Chemagnetics 4 mm double-resonance APEX HX magic-angle spinning (MAS) probe was used for all MAS experiments under a spinning rate of 10 kHz. The samples were packed into 4 mm OD standard zirconia rotors. Experimental boron chemical shift referencing, pulse calibration, and setup were done using powdered sodium borohydride (NaBH
4
), which has a chemical shift of −42.06 ppm relative to the primary standard, neat liquid BF
3
·OEt
2
at 0.0 ppm. The
11
B-selective 90° pulse widths used were 1.5 and 4 μs. A recycle delay of 5 s was used and a number of transients of 256 scans were acquired for the MAS experiments. A rotor-synchronized
11
B Hahn-echo spectrum was acquired for some samples in order to provide a spectrum with a better baseline. Finally, the NMR spectra were processed using MestReNova processing software (version 11.0.1).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3: 3.1. Effect of the Ratio of AB to DM
div.div:
Typical temperature and overall H
2
yield profiles for neat AB and 80 wt % AB (AB–DM = 4:1) at the set-point temperature 90 °C are shown in
Figure
2
. For neat AB thermolysis (
Figure
2
a), AB starts to release hydrogen gradually, and only 2.4 wt % H
2
yield was achieved for 30 min at the set-point temperature. For 80 wt % AB, however, a high yield of 9.1 wt % was obtained with extremely rapid hydrogen evolution. In addition, a small change in the sample temperature was observed for the neat AB thermolysis, whereas the sample temperature increased up to ∼250 °C in a few seconds with the addition of DM. The release of first and second hydrogens from AB is known as an exothermic reaction. Because of the slow reaction to release the first hydrogen for neat AB (
eq 1
), very little effect of exothermicity on the sample temperature was observed. It is likely that DM facilitates the release of the first hydrogen (
eq 1
), and the heat produced during this step induces the next dehydrogenation (
eq 2
). Therefore, the exothermic heat by the simultaneous release of the first and second hydrogens from AB seems to result in the sharp temperature rise.
Figure
2
b also shows that there is almost no change in H
2
yield profile after the sharp H
2
evolution, indicating that the dehydrogenation reaction is terminated immediately after the temperature rise. Finally, it was found that the onset temperature for dehydrogenation decreases by the addition of DM, suggesting that DM promotes AB thermolysis by decreasing the onset temperature while increasing dehydrogenation kinetics.

div.p:
Figure 2. Temperature and H
2
yield profiles at
P
i
= 14.7 psia, β = 2 °C/min, and
T
SP
= 90 °C for (a) neat AB and (b) 80 wt % AB (AB–DM = 4:1).

div.div:
The sample temperature and H
2
yield were further investigated with varying AB–DM ratios. As shown in
Figure
3
, the overall H
2
yield increases with the AB–DM ratio. By increasing the AB–DM ratio from 1:4 to 4:1, the hydrogen yield increased from 3.5 to 9.1 wt % and decreased to 3.3 wt % with a further increase in AB–DM ratio to 9:1.
Figure
3
also shows that only 2.4 wt % H
2
yield was achieved for neat AB. It can also be found from this figure that the reactor temperature at which sharp H
2
evolution begins increases with the AB loading ratio. The figure clearly shows that the H
2
yield profiles are quickly stabilized after the sharp H
2
evolution.

div.p:
Figure 3. H
2
yield profiles for various AB–DM ratios at
P
i
= 14.7 psia, β = 2 °C/min, and
T
SP
= 90 °C.

div.div:
The difference between the overall H
2
yield and H
2
equivalent is noteworthy. In addition to the H
2
yields presented in
Figure
3
, the corresponding H
2
molar equivalent with the AB–DM ratio is shown in
Figure
4
. As already observed in
Figure
3
, H
2
yield increases almost linearly with increasing AB–DM ratio up to 4:1. On the contrary, the H
2
molar equivalent decreased with the increasing ratio of AB in the mixed sample. The H
2
equivalents of 2.54 and 2.07 were determined for the AB–DM ratios of 1:4 and 2:3, respectively. These results suggest that more than two H
2
molecules are released from 1 mol of AB under these conditions, although other dehydrogenation pathways can be involved because of an the interaction between AB and DM (which will be discussed later). H
2
equivalents below 2 (1.82 and 1.75) were observed for the AB–DM ratios of 3:2 and 4:1, indicating that the second dehydrogenation of AB was not completed. For the AB–DM ratios of 1:4 and 2:3, however, the H
2
equivalents of 2.54 and 2.07 were determined, respectively. It clearly shows that more than two H
2
molecules are released from 1 mol of AB under these conditions although other dehydrogenation pathways can be involved. These results also clearly suggest that DM is a promising additive to enhance the hydrogen release properties of AB.

div.p:
Figure 4. Effect of AB–DM ratio on the H
2
yield and equivalent (
P
i
= 14.7 psia, β = 2 °C/min,
T
SP
= 90 °C).

div.div:
The H
2
yields and equivalents for different AB–DM ratios are summarized in
Table
1
. The table also includes the maximum sample temperature observed during the H
2
evolution. It was found that
T
S,max
increases with the AB portion in the sample. It is expected that the temperature rise is attributed to the total heat released by AB thermolysis, which is determined by both the AB amount and the extent of dehydrogenation (
eqs 1
and
2
).
Table 1. Maximum Temperatures and Gaseous Product Analysis for Different AB–DM Ratios

In this study, the effects of the set-point reactor temperature and heating rate were investigated. The standard operating conditions were: set-point reactor temperature (
T
SP
): 90 °C; heating rate (β): 2 °C/min; initial reactor pressure (
P
i
): 14.7 psia; and AB–DM = 3:2.
Figure
5
a shows that 85 °C is the minimum reactor temperature to obtain a high H
2
yield along with sharp evolution. Because of the rapid kinetics and reaction termination after the sharp evolution, consistent H
2
yield and equivalent (7.1–1.82) were observed for ≥85 °C. However, only ∼1.0 wt % H
2
yield was observed at 80 °C, which is not enough to drive the sharp evolution. As shown in
Figure
5
b, no significant effect of heating rate on H
2
yield was observed in this study. Similar to the effect of
T
SP
, consistent H
2
yield (∼7.1) and H
2
equivalent (∼1.8) were obtained by varying the heating rate from 0.5 to 5 °C/min.

div.p:
Figure 5. Effect of (a) set-point temperature and (b) heating rate on H
2
yield at AB–DM = 3:2 and
P
i
= 14.7 psia.

div.div:
Pan et al.
(21)
reported that the hydroxyl groups in mannitol promote thermal dehydrogenation of AB. They proposed that this promotion is attributed to the reaction between the B–H bonds in AB and O–H bonds in mannitol to release H
2
along with B–O bond formation, which follows the pathway of AB hydrolysis (
eq 3
).

Formation of NH
3
, the major by-product of AB hydrolysis, was determined by measuring the NH
3
concentration in the gaseous product after the reaction. This confirms experimentally the reaction mechanism proposed by Pan et al. In addition, it is important to quantify the ammonia concentration in the gaseous product as ammonia must be removed for use in PEM fuel cell applications.

Figure
6
shows the effect of AB–DM ratio on NH
3
concentration in the gaseous product of AB thermolysis, indicating a decrease of NH
3
concentration with increasing AB–DM ratio. For the 2:3 AB–DM ratio, 2.5 vol % of NH
3
was observed, whereas the formation of NH
3
dramatically decreased to 0.019 vol % by increasing the AB–DM ratio to 4:1. It is interesting that the amount of NH
3
formed by thermolysis of the AB–DM mixture is much smaller than that from neat AB (0.05 vol % NH
3
), which can be found in
Table
1
. This result is most likely because of the high H
2
evolution with a relatively small amount of DM, although DM was involved in hydrolysis to produce additional NH
3
. It can be further confirmed by the results given in
Table
1
that for the 9:1 AB–DM ratio, the NH
3
concentration increased to 1.0 vol %, which is higher than both concentrations from the neat AB and 4:1 AB–DM ratio. For the 9:1 AB–DM ratio, the H
2
release from AB was partially enhanced by hydrolysis in the presence of DM. Although sharp H
2
evolution was not observed for this ratio, both the maximum sample temperature and H
2
yield were higher than those for neat AB thermolysis (
Table
1
). The production of additional ammonia by hydrolysis between AB and DM appears to have increased the ammonia concentration despite more release of hydrogen.

div.p:
Figure 6. Effect of AB loading % on NH
3
formation at
P
i
= 14.7 psia, β = 2 °C/min, and
T
SP
= 90 °C.

div.div:
As NH
3
is a product of hydrolysis, it is expected that the NH
3
formation would increase with the content of the hydroxyl group in the AB–DM mixture. A further increase in DM loading, however, decreased the NH
3
concentration. For 1:4 AB–DM ratio, the NH
3
concentration decreased to 1.75 vol %. It may be because the amount of AB in the mixture is relatively smaller than that of the hydroxyl group in DM, indicating that the AB hydrolysis is limited by the amount of AB when using a low content of AB.

Using a mass spectrometer, gaseous products were analyzed to further understand the mechanism of thermal dehydrogenation of AB.
Figure
7
shows the transient analysis of H
2
(a) and NH
3
(b) for the neat AB and various AB–DM ratios. With an addition of DM, a sharp hydrogen evolution was observed as shown in
Figure
7
a1–a3. For neat AB, however, hydrogen began to be released near the reactor set-point temperature (
T
SP
). These results are in good agreement with our findings discussed in
Section 3.1
. With an increasing DM loading ratio, the time measured for the maximum hydrogen release was delayed (
Figure
7
a1–a3). In addition, a small shoulder was observed just before the main hydrogen release peak when DM was present. This indicates that the addition of DM results in the dehydrogenation of AB based on a reaction pathway other than thermolysis. During the ammonia measurement shown in
Figure
7
b1–b3, similar shoulders and patterns were shown at the same time as the peak of hydrogen release. It is noteworthy that the yield of ammonia from AB increased with increasing DM loading in the AB–DM mixture (
Figure
6
), suggesting that DM reacts with AB to produce NH
3
by hydrolysis. From these results, it is likely that AB releases hydrogen during hydrolysis with DM prior to thermolysis. It is interesting to note that ammonia was released for a longer time, compared to hydrogen. It can be seen from the figure that ammonia was still released although dehydrogenation was almost over. It is most likely that the product of thermolysis reacts with the residual hydroxyl group in DM to produce further ammonia.

div.p:
Figure 7. Transient analysis of gaseous products during AB dehydrogenation: (a) H
2
and (b) NH
3
for various AB–DM ratios.

div.div:
It is known that hydrogen release by both hydrolysis and thermolysis is exothermic. It is expected that the heat released by hydrolysis enables the initiation of thermolysis of AB. As a result, it is expected that the heat released during hydrolysis, as well as the heat during the first dehydrogenation step of thermolysis, drove the second step. It was found that the sample temperature increased dramatically to >170 °C (
Table
1
), which is sufficient to release the second H
2
from AB. Along with NH
3
and H
2
, the formation of by-products such as borazine and diborane was also analyzed. A peak of diborane was observed for neat AB, whereas borazine and diborane were not detected for AB thermolysis with DM.

The solid products of AB thermolysis with DM were characterized by solid-state
11
B NMR (
Figure
8
). As shown in
Figure
8
a–d, common peaks or broad shoulders appear at near 0, 5, and 20 ppm, corresponding to polyborazylene-like species.
(16,22,23)
Figure
8
f clearly shows these resonances increase with increasing AB–DM ratio, suggesting that the polyborazylene-like species resulting from the release of ∼2 H
2
equivalent during thermolysis decreases with DM loading. Although polyborazylene-like species was found to be the main solid product for higher AB–DM ratio (4:1), there is an additional shoulder (−5 to −30 ppm) corresponding to polyaminoborane, cyclotriborazane, and so forth, which result from the thermolysis to ∼1 H
2
equivalent.
(6,24)
These results are consistent with the finding from the H
2
equivalent in
Figure
4
. For higher AB–DM ratio, the release of the second hydrogen from AB was not completed.
Figure
8
d shows that the main peaks at 10 ppm are assigned to the B–O bond, a product of AB hydrolysis.
(25)
In contrast to the case of polyborazylene-like species, the peak corresponding to the B–O bond increased with increasing DM loading %, suggesting that the B–O bond by AB hydrolysis increased with the hydroxyl groups in DM. This result is in good agreement with the observation that NH
3
formation by AB hydrolysis increases with DM loading %. As DM loading % decreased, the thermolysis products such as polyborazylene-like species increased, whereas the B–O bond, the hydrolysis product, decreased.

div.p:
Figure 8.
11
B solid-state NMR spectrum at AB–DM of (a) 1:4, (b) 2:3, (c) 3:2, (d) 4:1, (e) neat AB, and (f) combined NMR spectra for all AB–DM ratios.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In the present work, DM (C
6
H
8
(OH)
6
) as an additive was introduced to improve the performance of thermal dehydrogenation of AB. For neat AB thermolysis, hydrogen was released from AB gradually. With increasing AB loading %, however, the hydrogen yield by thermolysis increased, whereas the contribution by hydrolysis increased with DM loading %, which was confirmed by NH
3
formation. It was found that with the addition of DM, a high hydrogen yield of 9.1 wt % was obtained at 90 °C with an extremely rapid hydrogen evolution, suggesting that DM promotes AB thermolysis by decreasing the onset temperature while increasing dehydrogenation kinetics.
11
B solid-state NMR shows that the B–O bond increased with increasing DM loading %, indicating that the B–O bond by AB hydrolysis increased with the hydroxyl groups in DM. This result is in good agreement with the observation that NH
3
formation by AB hydrolysis increases with DM loading %. On the contrary, it was found that the thermolysis product such as polyborazylene-like species decreased with DM loading %. Our results suggest that the dehydrogenation of AB with DM can be an attractive method for PEM fuel cell-powered hydrogen storage.

High capacity hydrogen storage materials: attributes for automotive applications and techniques for materials discovery
Yang, Jun; Sudik, Andrea; Wolverton, Christopher; Siegel, Donald J.

A review. Widespread adoption of H as a vehicular fuel depends critically upon the ability to store H on-board at high volumetric and gravimetric densities, as well as on the ability to ext./insert it at sufficiently rapid rates. As current storage methods based on phys. means-high-pressure gas or (cryogenic) liquefaction-are unlikely to satisfy targets for performance and cost, a global research effort focusing on the development of chem. means for storing H in condensed phases has recently emerged. At present, no known material exhibits a combination of properties that would enable high-vol. automotive applications. Thus new materials with improved performance, or new approaches to the synthesis and/or processing of existing materials, are highly desirable. In this crit. review the authors provide a practical introduction to the field of H storage materials research, with an emphasis on (i) the properties necessary for a viable storage material, (ii) the computational and exptl. techniques commonly employed in detg. these attributes, and (iii) the classes of materials being pursued as candidate storage compds. Starting from the general requirements of a fuel cell vehicle, the authors summarize how these requirements translate into desired characteristics for the H storage material. Key amongst these are: (a) high gravimetric and volumetric H d., (b) thermodn. that allow for reversible H uptake/release under near-ambient conditions, and (c) fast reaction kinetics. To further illustrate these attributes, the 4 major classes of candidate storage materials-conventional metal hydrides, chem. hydrides, complex hydrides, and sorbent systems-are introduced and their resp. performance and prospects for improvement in each of these areas is discussed. Finally, the authors review the most valuable exptl. and computational techniques for detg. these attributes, highlighting how an approach that couples computational modeling with expts. can significantly accelerate the discovery of novel storage materials (155 refs.).

A review. H-rich B-contg. compds. received attention as potential H storage media for vehicular application. Progress in material discovery, material compn./structure tailoring, catalyst identification and regeneration chem. was made. Li tetrahydroborate-related materials exhibit the highest reversible H capacity via solid-gas reactions. Catalytic hydrolysis of Na tetrahydroborate offers an on-demand H generation system for vehicular application. NH3 borane-related materials exhibit a satisfactory combination of material properties that are suited for on-board H sources, coupled with significant advances in spent fuel regeneration. The progress of these representative reversible or irreversible material systems is presented.

A review. The authors present a comprehensive, detailed, and crit. review of the subject of using ammonia borane as a hydrogen storage material, covering developments up to early 2010. Ammonia-borane is a white cryst. solid that was first prepd. by Shore and Parry in 1955. The review presents the various syntheses of ammonia-borane, and then discusses the phys. properties of this compd. in detail. The paper then considers ammonia-borane as a hydrogen donor, describing the thermal decompn. in the solid state and in soln., combined with computational studies of these and then a brief discussion of transition metal catalyzed dehydrocoupling reactions of ammonia-borane and the exptl. activity of the catalysts, including the mechanistic details. The next section deals with effecting hydrogen release by incorporating ammonia-borane into scaffolds or using ionic liqs. In the fifth section, the use of main group metal amidoboranes as hydrogen contg. materials is described. The paper discusses another chem. different hydrogen release approach from ammonia-borane (and primary and secondary amineboranes in general), involving metal catalyzed solvolysis in a protic solvent. In section 7, N-methylated amine-boranes are reviewed because they provide a useful comparison to ammonia-borane, but catalyzed dehydrogenation or dehydrocoupling aspects are not dealt with. In the same section the authors discuss the structure and thermal decompn. of alternatives to ammonia-borane, which have received recent interest, such as ammonia-triborane, hydrazine-borane, and guanidinium borohydride. The last topic is the recyclability of spent fuel from ammonia-borane.

Among chem. hydrides, NH3 borane (AB) is of interest as a H storage material due to its high H capacity (19.6%). The recently developed hydrothermolysis process was studied over a wide range of AB wt. percentages (wt. %) in H2O, pressures and heating rates. H yield and thermal characteristics were influenced by these operating conditions. NH3 generation was also obsd. during AB hydrothermolysis, where 14-53% of AB was converted to NH3 depending on the reaction conditions. It is remarkable that some AB (2-4%) was converted to NH3, which must be removed for use in p exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells, even by neat thermolysis. Also during the hydrothermolysis reaction at Treactor of 85°, the Tsample can exceed 500°, where AB can be completely decompd. to B nitride (BN). The 11B NMR characterization of hydrothermolysis products showed compds. with B-O and B-N bonds. This paper suggests directions for future research to identify optimal conditions, where the hydrothermolysis process provides the best balance between H2 yield and undesirable products, for PEM fuel cell vehicle applications.

The thermal decompn. of borazane BH3NH3 in the temp. range up to 500 K has been studied by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetry (TG) combined with FTIR spectroscopic and mass spectrometric anal. of the gas phase. Above 340 K borazane is decompd. in stages as the temp. is increased. The exothermic decompn. is accompanied by the release of approx. 2.2 mol H2/mol BH3NH3. This corresponds to a remarkable hydrogen storage d. of 14.3 mass% related to the mass of borazane. In the gas phase above the solid decompn. residue, monomeric aminoborane (BH2NH2), borazine (BHNH)3, which is the boron-nitrogen analog of benzene, and traces of diborane B2H6 were found besides hydrogen. The release of significant quantities of borazine was obsd. only at temps. above 400 K.

Current promising methods to release H from NH3 borane (NH3BH3, AB; 19.6% H2) including neat thermolysis, thermolysis in ionic liq. bmimCl with or without p sponge, thermolysis with nano-BN and hydrothermolysis, were studied for H yield and NH3 formation. Even trace moisture influences AB dehydrogenation significantly. The hydrothermolysis at 85° (13.5% H2, 1 mol.% NH3) and thermolysis in bmimCl with 3% moisture at 110° (13% H2, 0.2 mol.% NH3) methods are the most promising. Since the target for a p exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell is an NH3 concn. <0.1 ppm, different purifn. methods were evaluated. Using expts. and simulations, the proposed NH3 removal method, involving absorption in H2O followed by adsorption on C, was optimized and tested. With high H yield and an effective method to remove NH3 and borazine, AB dehydrogenation is an attractive approach to generate H for PEM fuel cell vehicles.

Ammonia borane (NH3BH3, AB), contg. 19.6 wt% hydrogen, is a promising hydrogen storage material for use in proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEM FC) powered vehicles. We recently demonstrated that using quartz wool, the highest H2 yield (2.1-2.3H2 equivalent) values were obtained by neat AB thermolysis near PEM FC operating temps., along with rapid kinetics, without the use of either catalyst or chem. additives. It was found that quartz wool minimizes sample expansion and facilitates the prodn. of diamoniate of diborane (DADB), which is a key intermediate for the release of hydrogen from AB. It was also found that only trace amt. of ammonia (<10 ppm) is produced during dehydrogenation reaction and spent AB products are found to be polyborazylene-like species, which can be efficiently regenerated using currently demonstrated methods. The results indicate that our proposed method is the most promising one available in the literature to-date for hydrogen storage, and could be used in PEM FC based vehicle applications.

Ammonia borane (AB, NH3BH3) is a promising hydrogen storage material for use in proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell applications. In this study, the effect of boric acid on AB dehydrogenation was investigated. Our study shows that boric acid is a promising additive to decrease onset temp. as well as to enhance hydrogen release kinetics for AB thermolysis. With heating, boric acid forms tetrahydroxyborate ion along with some water released from boric acid itself. It is believed that this ion serves as Lewis acid which catalyzes AB dehydrogenation. Using boric acid, we obtained high H2 yield (11.5 wt% overall H2 yield, 2.23 H2 equivalent) at 85 °C, PEM fuel cell operating temps., along with rapid kinetics. In addn., only trace amt. of NH3 (20-30 ppm) was detected in the gaseous product. The spent AB solid product was found to be polyborazylene-like species. The results suggest that the addn. of boric acid to AB is promising for hydrogen storage, and could be used in PEM fuel cell based vehicles.

The complementary use of 15N and 11B NMR expts., supported by d. functional theory calcns. of the chem. shift tensors, provided insights into the dehydrogenation mechanism of AB-insights that were not available by 11B NMR alone. Specifically, highly branched polyaminoborane derivs. form from AB via oligomerization in the head-to-tail manner, which then transform directly into hexagonal B nitride analog through the dehydrocyclization reaction, bypassing the formation of polyiminoborane.

A new synthetic procedure to make the condensed phase hydrogen storage material, ammonia borane (NH3BH3, abbreviated as AB), is described and compared with previous literature procedures. Ammonia borane with a gravimetric d. ca. 194 gm H2 kg-1 and a volumetric d. ca. 146 H2 L-1, is a promising chem. hydrogen storage material for fuel cell powered applications. The work shows that ammonium borohydride, NH4BH4, formed in situ by the metathesis of NH4X and MBH4 salts (M = Na, Li; X = Cl, F) in liq. NH3, can be induced to decomp. in an org. ether to yield AB in near quant. yield. The purity of the AB prepd. by this one-pot synthetic strategy is sufficient to meet the thermal stability requirements for on-board hydrogen storage.

The effects of metal-based additives in a wide range of elements doping into ammonia borane (AB) were systematically studied. Pure transition metals in period 4 and total of 17 metal chlorides were selected as additives and ball-milled with AB. Metal chloride additives were effective to decrease H2 desorption temp. and the amts. of byproduct gas emissions of AB, whereas pure transition metals did not show any ability because they did not work as Lewis acids. The strong correlation between H2 desorption temp. and the Pauling electronegativity of metal (χp) was obsd. Mn+ of MCln would work as Lewis acid to initiate the AB dehydrocoupling reaction. The amt. of NH3 emission was correlated with the ionic radius of M, suggesting MCln·mNH3 complexes be formed in this system. AB-CuCl2 and AB-AgCl mixts. showed the similar H2 desorption processes. The Cl-contg. intermediate phase would destabilize AB during reaction.

Promoted H release from NH3 borane (NH3BH3, AB) with mannitol (C6H8(OH)6, MA) additive is reported. For the MA/2AB sample, the dehydrogenation temp. is lowered by ∼25° compared to that of neat AB, the liberation of undesired byproduct borazine is suppressed, and the released NH3 can be removed by using anhyd. MgCl2 as absorber. The analyses of Raman, FTIR spectroscopy and 11B NMR spectroscopy demonstrate the breaking of B-N, B-H and O-H bonds and the formation of B-O bonds for the dehydrogenation process of MA/2AB. These results suggest a solid-state dehydrogenation reaction between AB and MA: the B-Hδ- bonds in AB and the O-Hδ+ bonds in MA combine with each other to release H2. Also, the use of the perfect -OH carrier MA as additive leads to a straightforward understanding of the improved dehydrogenation of AB under the effect of hydroxyl groups in the solid state.

Zn(BH4)2·2NH3, a new ammine metal borohydride, has been synthesized via simply ball-milling a mixt. of ZnCl2·2NH3/2LiBH4. Structure anal. shows that the subsequent complex has a monoclinic structure with unit-cell parameters of a = 6.392(4) Å, b = 8.417(6) Å, c = 6.388(4) Å and β = 92.407(4)° and space group P21, in which Zn atoms coordinate with two BH4 groups and two NH3 groups. The interat. distances reported herein show that Zn-H bonding in Zn(BH4)2·2NH3 is shorter than Ca-H bonds in Ca(BH4)2·2NH3 and Mg-H in Mg(BH4)2·2NH3. This reduced bond contact leads to an increase in the ionic character of H. This study is able to show a good correlation between the reduced M-H distance and enhanced dehydrogenation behavior of the hydride material. Dehydrogenation results showed that Zn(BH4)2·2NH3/LiCl is able to release 5.36 wt% hydrogen (corresponding to 8.9 wt% for pure Zn(BH4)2·2NH3) below 115 °C within 15 min without concomitant release of undesirable gases such as ammonia and/or boranes, thereby demonstrating the potential of Zn(BH4)2·2NH3 to be used as a solid hydrogen storage material.

The thermal decompn. pathway of sodium amidoborane (NaAB; NaNH2BH3) has been investigated in detail by using solid state NMR spectroscopy. . 23Na MAS/3QMAS NMR spectra suggested that NaH and an amorphous Na-N-B-H phase started to be formed as decompn. products even at 79 °C, although NaAB was prepd. from NaH and NH3BH3 by ball milling at room temp. Based on the quant. analyses of the 23Na MAS spectra, we proposed a decompn. reaction to 200 °C to be NaNH2BH3 → Na0.5NBH0.5 + 0.5NaH + 2.0H2. The hypothetical phase Na0.5NBH0.5 is amorphous, where the basic mol. unit of the original NaAB is polymd. into a [-B=N-]n network structure. It was also found that the diammoniate of diborane (DADB) and polyaminoborane (PAB) were not formed during the decompn. of NaAB, which are both key compds. on the pyrolysis of ammonia borane (AB).

Using in situ 11B NMR spectroscopy, the overall rate of K2Cl6Pt-catalyzed hydrolysis of the AB complex is third-order. High capacity hydrogen storage materials: attributes for automotive applications and techniques for materials discovery
Yang, Jun; Sudik, Andrea; Wolverton, Christopher; Siegel, Donald J.

A review. Widespread adoption of H as a vehicular fuel depends critically upon the ability to store H on-board at high volumetric and gravimetric densities, as well as on the ability to ext./insert it at sufficiently rapid rates. As current storage methods based on phys. means-high-pressure gas or (cryogenic) liquefaction-are unlikely to satisfy targets for performance and cost, a global research effort focusing on the development of chem. means for storing H in condensed phases has recently emerged. At present, no known material exhibits a combination of properties that would enable high-vol. automotive applications. Thus new materials with improved performance, or new approaches to the synthesis and/or processing of existing materials, are highly desirable. In this crit. review the authors provide a practical introduction to the field of H storage materials research, with an emphasis on (i) the properties necessary for a viable storage material, (ii) the computational and exptl. techniques commonly employed in detg. these attributes, and (iii) the classes of materials being pursued as candidate storage compds. Starting from the general requirements of a fuel cell vehicle, the authors summarize how these requirements translate into desired characteristics for the H storage material. Key amongst these are: (a) high gravimetric and volumetric H d., (b) thermodn. that allow for reversible H uptake/release under near-ambient conditions, and (c) fast reaction kinetics. To further illustrate these attributes, the 4 major classes of candidate storage materials-conventional metal hydrides, chem. hydrides, complex hydrides, and sorbent systems-are introduced and their resp. performance and prospects for improvement in each of these areas is discussed. Finally, the authors review the most valuable exptl. and computational techniques for detg. these attributes, highlighting how an approach that couples computational modeling with expts. can significantly accelerate the discovery of novel storage materials (155 refs.).

A review. H-rich B-contg. compds. received attention as potential H storage media for vehicular application. Progress in material discovery, material compn./structure tailoring, catalyst identification and regeneration chem. was made. Li tetrahydroborate-related materials exhibit the highest reversible H capacity via solid-gas reactions. Catalytic hydrolysis of Na tetrahydroborate offers an on-demand H generation system for vehicular application. NH3 borane-related materials exhibit a satisfactory combination of material properties that are suited for on-board H sources, coupled with significant advances in spent fuel regeneration. The progress of these representative reversible or irreversible material systems is presented.

A review. The authors present a comprehensive, detailed, and crit. review of the subject of using ammonia borane as a hydrogen storage material, covering developments up to early 2010. Ammonia-borane is a white cryst. solid that was first prepd. by Shore and Parry in 1955. The review presents the various syntheses of ammonia-borane, and then discusses the phys. properties of this compd. in detail. The paper then considers ammonia-borane as a hydrogen donor, describing the thermal decompn. in the solid state and in soln., combined with computational studies of these and then a brief discussion of transition metal catalyzed dehydrocoupling reactions of ammonia-borane and the exptl. activity of the catalysts, including the mechanistic details. The next section deals with effecting hydrogen release by incorporating ammonia-borane into scaffolds or using ionic liqs. In the fifth section, the use of main group metal amidoboranes as hydrogen contg. materials is described. The paper discusses another chem. different hydrogen release approach from ammonia-borane (and primary and secondary amineboranes in general), involving metal catalyzed solvolysis in a protic solvent. In section 7, N-methylated amine-boranes are reviewed because they provide a useful comparison to ammonia-borane, but catalyzed dehydrogenation or dehydrocoupling aspects are not dealt with. In the same section the authors discuss the structure and thermal decompn. of alternatives to ammonia-borane, which have received recent interest, such as ammonia-triborane, hydrazine-borane, and guanidinium borohydride. The last topic is the recyclability of spent fuel from ammonia-borane.

Hwang, Hyun Tae; Al-Kukhun, Ahmad; Varma, Arvind

Among chem. hydrides, NH3 borane (AB) is of interest as a H storage material due to its high H capacity (19.6%). The recently developed hydrothermolysis process was studied over a wide range of AB wt. percentages (wt. %) in H2O, pressures and heating rates. H yield and thermal characteristics were influenced by these operating conditions. NH3 generation was also obsd. during AB hydrothermolysis, where 14-53% of AB was converted to NH3 depending on the reaction conditions. It is remarkable that some AB (2-4%) was converted to NH3, which must be removed for use in p exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells, even by neat thermolysis. Also during the hydrothermolysis reaction at Treactor of 85°, the Tsample can exceed 500°, where AB can be completely decompd. to B nitride (BN). The 11B NMR characterization of hydrothermolysis products showed compds. with B-O and B-N bonds. This paper suggests directions for future research to identify optimal conditions, where the hydrothermolysis process provides the best balance between H2 yield and undesirable products, for PEM fuel cell vehicle applications.

A review of progress in catalysis research to control the rate and extent of H release from H3NBH3 as well as the regeneration of H3NBH3. H3NBH3 is an intriguing mol. for chem. H storage applications. With protic N-H and hydridic B-H bonds, 3 H atoms per main group element, and a low mol. wt., H3NBH3 has the potential to meet the stringent gravimetric and volumetric H storage capacity targets needed for transportation applications. Devising an energy-efficient chem. process to regenerate H3NBH3 from de-hydrogenated BNHx material is an important step towards realization of a sustainable transportation fuel.

The thermal decompn. of borazane BH3NH3 in the temp. range up to 500 K has been studied by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetry (TG) combined with FTIR spectroscopic and mass spectrometric anal. of the gas phase. Above 340 K borazane is decompd. in stages as the temp. is increased. The exothermic decompn. is accompanied by the release of approx. 2.2 mol H2/mol BH3NH3. This corresponds to a remarkable hydrogen storage d. of 14.3 mass% related to the mass of borazane. In the gas phase above the solid decompn. residue, monomeric aminoborane (BH2NH2), borazine (BHNH)3, which is the boron-nitrogen analog of benzene, and traces of diborane B2H6 were found besides hydrogen. The release of significant quantities of borazine was obsd. only at temps. above 400 K.

Current promising methods to release H from NH3 borane (NH3BH3, AB; 19.6% H2) including neat thermolysis, thermolysis in ionic liq. bmimCl with or without p sponge, thermolysis with nano-BN and hydrothermolysis, were studied for H yield and NH3 formation. Even trace moisture influences AB dehydrogenation significantly. The hydrothermolysis at 85° (13.5% H2, 1 mol.% NH3) and thermolysis in bmimCl with 3% moisture at 110° (13% H2, 0.2 mol.% NH3) methods are the most promising. Since the target for a p exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell is an NH3 concn. <0.1 ppm, different purifn. methods were evaluated. Using expts. and simulations, the proposed NH3 removal method, involving absorption in H2O followed by adsorption on C, was optimized and tested. With high H yield and an effective method to remove NH3 and borazine, AB dehydrogenation is an attractive approach to generate H for PEM fuel cell vehicles.

Ammonia borane (H3N-BH3, AB) is a lightwt. material contg. a high d. of hydrogen (H2) that can be readily liberated for use in fuel cell-powered applications. However, in the absence of a straightforward, efficient method for regenerating AB from dehydrogenated polymeric spent fuel, its full potential as a viable H2 storage material will not be realized. It is demonstrated that the spent fuel type derived from the removal of greater than two equiv. of H2 per mol. of AB (i.e., polyborazylene, PB) can be converted back to AB nearly quant. by 24-h treatment with hydrazine (N2H4) in liq. ammonia (NH3) at 40° in a sealed pressure vessel.

Ammonia borane (NH3BH3, AB), contg. 19.6 wt% hydrogen, is a promising hydrogen storage material for use in proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEM FC) powered vehicles. We recently demonstrated that using quartz wool, the highest H2 yield (2.1-2.3H2 equivalent) values were obtained by neat AB thermolysis near PEM FC operating temps., along with rapid kinetics, without the use of either catalyst or chem. additives. It was found that quartz wool minimizes sample expansion and facilitates the prodn. of diamoniate of diborane (DADB), which is a key intermediate for the release of hydrogen from AB. It was also found that only trace amt. of ammonia (<10 ppm) is produced during dehydrogenation reaction and spent AB products are found to be polyborazylene-like species, which can be efficiently regenerated using currently demonstrated methods. The results indicate that our proposed method is the most promising one available in the literature to-date for hydrogen storage, and could be used in PEM FC based vehicle applications.

Ammonia borane (AB, NH3BH3) is a promising hydrogen storage material for use in proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell applications. In this study, the effect of boric acid on AB dehydrogenation was investigated. Our study shows that boric acid is a promising additive to decrease onset temp. as well as to enhance hydrogen release kinetics for AB thermolysis. With heating, boric acid forms tetrahydroxyborate ion along with some water released from boric acid itself. It is believed that this ion serves as Lewis acid which catalyzes AB dehydrogenation. Using boric acid, we obtained high H2 yield (11.5 wt% overall H2 yield, 2.23 H2 equivalent) at 85 °C, PEM fuel cell operating temps., along with rapid kinetics. In addn., only trace amt. of NH3 (20-30 ppm) was detected in the gaseous product. The spent AB solid product was found to be polyborazylene-like species. The results suggest that the addn. of boric acid to AB is promising for hydrogen storage, and could be used in PEM fuel cell based vehicles.

Specifically, highly branched polyaminoborane derivs. form from AB via oligomerization in the head-to-tail manner, which then transform directly into hexagonal B nitride analog through the dehydrocyclization reaction, bypassing the formation of polyiminoborane.

A new synthetic procedure to make the condensed phase hydrogen storage material, ammonia borane (NH3BH3, abbreviated as AB), is described and compared with previous literature procedures. Ammonia borane with a gravimetric d. ca. 194 gm H2 kg-1 and a volumetric d. ca. 146 H2 L-1, is a promising chem. hydrogen storage material for fuel cell powered applications. The purity of the AB prepd. by this one-pot synthetic strategy is sufficient to meet the thermal stability requirements for on-board hydrogen storage.

Promoted H release from NH3 borane (NH3BH3, AB) with mannitol (C6H8(OH)6, MA) additive is reported. For the MA/2AB sample, the dehydrogenation temp. is lowered by ∼25° compared to that of neat AB, the liberation of undesired byproduct borazine is suppressed, and the released NH3 can be removed by using anhyd. MgCl2 as absorber. The analyses of Raman, FTIR spectroscopy and 11B NMR spectroscopy demonstrate the breaking of B-N, B-H and O-H bonds and the formation of B-O bonds for the dehydrogenation process of MA/2AB. These results suggest a solid-state dehydrogenation reaction between AB and MA: the B-Hδ- bonds in AB and the O-Hδ+ bonds in MA combine with each other to release H2. Also, the use of the perfect -OH carrier MA as additive leads to a straightforward understanding of the improved dehydrogenation of AB under the effect of hydroxyl groups in the solid state.

Structure and decomposition of zinc borohydride ammonia adduct: towards a pure hydrogen release
Gu, Qinfen; Gao, Liang; Guo, Yanhui; Tan, Yingbin; Tang, Ziwei; Wallwork, Kia S.; Zhang, Feiwu; Yu, Xuebin

Zn(BH4)2·2NH3, a new ammine metal borohydride, has been synthesized via simply ball-milling a mixt. of ZnCl2·2NH3/2LiBH4. Structure anal. shows that the subsequent complex has a monoclinic structure with unit-cell parameters of a = 6.392(4) Å, b = 8.417(6) Å, c = 6.388(4) Å and β = 92.407(4)° and space group P21, in which Zn atoms coordinate with two BH4 groups and two NH3 groups. The interat. distances reported herein show that Zn-H bonding in Zn(BH4)2·2NH3 is shorter than Ca-H bonds in Ca(BH4)2·2NH3 and Mg-H in Mg(BH4)2·2NH3. This reduced bond contact leads to an increase in the ionic character of H. This study is able to show a good correlation between the reduced M-H distance and enhanced dehydrogenation behavior of the hydride material. Dehydrogenation results showed that Zn(BH4)2·2NH3/LiCl is able to release 5.36 wt% hydrogen (corresponding to 8.9 wt% for pure Zn(BH4)2·2NH3) below 115 °C within 15 min without concomitant release of undesirable gases such as ammonia and/or boranes, thereby demonstrating the potential of Zn(BH4)2·2NH3 to be used as a solid hydrogen storage material.

Polyborazilene, a precursor for hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) ceramics, has been extensively characterized by 15N and 11B MAS NMR. The various B and N sites have been identified according to their first neighboring atoms as well as to the second ones in the case of 15N and have also been quantified. This study demonstrates that a suitable choice of NMR techniques together with the use of isotopic enrichment can lead to a large improvement in spectral resoln., which allows better understanding of such complex BN preceramic polymer structures.

Shimoda, Keiji; Zhang, Yu; Ichikawa, Takayuki; Miyaoka, Hiroki; Kojima, Yoshitsugu

The thermal decompn. pathway of sodium amidoborane (NaAB; NaNH2BH3) has been investigated in detail by using solid state NMR spectroscopy. . 23Na MAS/3QMAS NMR spectra suggested that NaH and an amorphous Na-N-B-H phase started to be formed as decompn. products even at 79 °C, although NaAB was prepd. from NaH and NH3BH3 by ball milling at room temp. Based on the quant. analyses of the 23Na MAS spectra, we proposed a decompn. reaction to 200 °C to be NaNH2BH3 → Na0.5NBH0.5 + 0.5NaH + 2.0H2. The hypothetical phase Na0.5NBH0.5 is amorphous, where the basic mol. unit of the original NaAB is polymd. into a [-B=N-]n network structure. It was also found that the diammoniate of diborane (DADB) and polyaminoborane (PAB) were not formed during the decompn. of NaAB, which are both key compds. on the pyrolysis of ammonia borane (AB).

A new process for generating H through room temp. hydrolysis of the AB complex using small amts. of Pt group metal catalyst, was studied. Using in situ 11B NMR spectroscopy, the overall rate of K2Cl6Pt-catalyzed hydrolysis of the AB complex is third-order. The pre-exponential factor, A, and the activation energy, Ea, of the Arrhenius equation, ln k = ln A-Ea/RT, are: A = 1.6 × 1011 L/mol-1/s-1 and Ea = 86.6 kJ/mol for temp. range 25-35°. XPS of the residue suggested that the Pt salt was reduced from Pt4+ to Pt0 in the reaction and XRD of the residue showed crystd. single-phase boric acid.
